text: ਤਾਰ੍ਯਉ ਸੰਸਾਰੁ ਮਾਯਾ ਮਦ ਮੋਹਿਤ ਅੰਮ੍ਰਿਤ ਨਾਮੁ ਦੀਅਉ ਸਮਰਥੁ ॥

translation.text: The Universe is intoxicated with the wine of Maya, but it has been saved; the All-powerful Guru has blessed it with the Ambrosial Nectar of the Naam.

transliteration.text: tāryau sansār māyā mad mōhit anmrit nām dīau samarath .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਫੁਨਿ ਕੀਰਤਿਵੰਤ ਸਦਾ ਸੁਖ ਸੰਪਤਿ ਰਿਧਿ ਅਰੁ ਸਿਧਿ ਨ ਛੋਡਇ ਸਥੁ ॥

translation.text: And, the Praiseworthy Guru is blessed with eternal peace, wealth and prosperity; the supernatural spiritual powers of the Siddhis never leave him.

transliteration.text: phun kīrativant sadā sukh sanpat ridh ar sidh n shōdai sath .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਦਾਨਿ ਬਡੌ ਅਤਿਵੰਤੁ ਮਹਾਬਲਿ ਸੇਵਕਿ ਦਾਸਿ ਕਹਿਓ ਇਹੁ ਤਥੁ ॥

translation.text: His Gifts are vast and great; His awesome Power is supreme. Your humble servant and slave speaks this truth.

transliteration.text: dān badau ativant mahābal sēvak dās kahiō ih tath .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਤਾਹਿ ਕਹਾ ਪਰਵਾਹ ਕਾਹੂ ਕੀ ਜਾ ਕੈ ਬਸੀਸਿ ਧਰਿਓ ਗੁਰਿ ਹਥੁ ॥੭॥੪੯॥

translation.text: One, upon whose head the Guru has placed His Hand - with whom should he be concerned? ||7||49||

transliteration.text: tāh kahā paravāh kāhū kī jā kai basīs dhariō gur hath .7.49.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਤੀਨਿ ਭਵਨ ਭਰਪੂਰਿ ਰਹਿਓ ਸੋਈ ॥

translation.text: He is totally pervading and permeating the three realms;

transliteration.text: tīn bhavan bharapūr rahiō sōī .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Balh
author.description:
Poet Balh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਅਪਨ ਸਰਸੁ ਕੀਅਉ ਨ ਜਗਤ ਕੋਈ ॥

translation.text: in all the world, He has not created another like Himself.

transliteration.text: apan saras kīau n jagat kōī .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Balh
author.description:
Poet Balh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਆਪੁਨ ਆਪੁ ਆਪ ਹੀ ਉਪਾਯਉ ॥

translation.text: He Himself created Himself.

transliteration.text: āpun āp āp hī upāyau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Balh
author.description:
Poet Balh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਸੁਰਿ ਨਰ ਅਸੁਰ ਅੰਤੁ ਨਹੀ ਪਾਯਉ ॥

translation.text: The angels, human beings and demons have not found His limits.

transliteration.text: sur nar asur ant nahī pāyau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Balh
author.description:
Poet Balh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਪਾਯਉ ਨਹੀ ਅੰਤੁ ਸੁਰੇ ਅਸੁਰਹ ਨਰ ਗਣ ਗੰਧ੍ਰਬ ਖੋਜੰਤ ਫਿਰੇ ॥

translation.text: The angels, demons and human beings have not found His limits; the heavenly heralds and celestial singers wander around, searching for Him.

transliteration.text: pāyau nahī ant surē asurah nar gan gandhrab khōjant phirē .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Balh
author.description:
Poet Balh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਅਬਿਨਾਸੀ ਅਚਲੁ ਅਜੋਨੀ ਸੰਭਉ ਪੁਰਖੋਤਮੁ ਅਪਾਰ ਪਰੇ ॥

translation.text: The Eternal, Imperishable, Unmoving and Unchanging, Unborn, Self-Existent, Primal Being of the Soul, the Infinity of the Infinite,

transliteration.text: abināsī achal ajōnī sanbhau purakhōtam apār parē .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Balh
author.description:
Poet Balh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਕਰਣ ਕਾਰਣ ਸਮਰਥੁ ਸਦਾ ਸੋਈ ਸਰਬ ਜੀਅ ਮਨਿ ਧ੍ਯਾਇਯਉ ॥

translation.text: the Eternal All-powerful Cause of causes - all beings meditate on Him in their minds.

transliteration.text: karan kāran samarath sadā sōī sarab jī man dhyāiyau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Balh
author.description:
Poet Balh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਸ੍ਰੀ ਗੁਰ ਰਾਮਦਾਸ ਜਯੋ ਜਯ ਜਗ ਮਹਿ ਤੈ ਹਰਿ ਪਰਮ ਪਦੁ ਪਾਇਯਉ ॥੧॥

translation.text: O Great and Supreme Guru Raam Daas, Your Victory resounds across the universe. You have attained the supreme status of the Lord. ||1||

transliteration.text: srī gur rāmadās jayō jay jag mah tai har param pad pāiyau .1.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Balh
author.description:
Poet Balh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਸਤਿਗੁਰਿ ਨਾਨਕਿ ਭਗਤਿ ਕਰੀ ਇਕ ਮਨਿ ਤਨੁ ਮਨੁ ਧਨੁ ਗੋਬਿੰਦ ਦੀਅਉ ॥

translation.text: Nanak, the True Guru, worships God single-mindedly; He surrenders His body, mind and wealth to the Lord of the Universe.

transliteration.text: satigur nānak bhagat karī ik man tan man dhan gōbind dīau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Balh
author.description:
Poet Balh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਅੰਗਦਿ ਅਨੰਤ ਮੂਰਤਿ ਨਿਜ ਧਾਰੀ ਅਗਮ ਗ੍ਯਾਨਿ ਰਸਿ ਰਸ੍ਯਉ ਹੀਅਉ ॥

translation.text: The Infinite Lord enshrined His Own Image in Guru Angad. In His heart, He delights in the spiritual wisdom of the Unfathomable Lord.

transliteration.text: angad anant mūrat nij dhārī agam gyān ras rasyau hīau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Balh
author.description:
Poet Balh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਗੁਰਿ ਅਮਰਦਾਸਿ ਕਰਤਾਰੁ ਕੀਅਉ ਵਸਿ ਵਾਹੁ ਵਾਹੁ ਕਰਿ ਧ੍ਯਾਇਯਉ ॥

translation.text: Guru Amar Daas brought the Creator Lord under His control. Waaho! Waaho! Meditate on Him!

transliteration.text: gur amaradās karatār kīau vas vāh vāh kar dhyāiyau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.description:

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਸ੍ਰੀ ਗੁਰ ਰਾਮਦਾਸ ਜਯੋ ਜਯ ਜਗ ਮਹਿ ਤੈ ਹਰਿ ਪਰਮ ਪਦੁ ਪਾਇਯਉ ॥੨॥

translation.text: O Great and Supreme Guru Raam Daas, Your Victory resounds across the universe. You have attained the supreme status of the Lord. ||2||

transliteration.text: srī gur rāmadās jayō jay jag mah tai har param pad pāiyau .2.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਨਾਰਦੁ ਧ੍ਰੂ ਪ੍ਰਹਲਾਦੁ ਸੁਦਾਮਾ ਪੁਬ ਭਗਤ ਹਰਿ ਕੇ ਜੁ ਗਣੰ ॥

translation.text: Naarad, Dhroo, Prahlaad and Sudaamaa are accounted among the Lord's devotees of the past.

transliteration.text: nārad dhrū prahalād sudāmā pub bhagat har kē j ganan .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Balh
author.description:
Poet Balh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਅੰਬਰੀਕੁ ਜਯਦੇਵ ਤ੍ਰਿਲੋਚਨੁ ਨਾਮਾ ਅਵਰੁ ਕਬੀਰੁ ਭਣੰ ॥

translation.text: Ambreek, Jai Dayv, Trilochan, Naam Dayv and Kabeer are also remembered.

transliteration.text: anbarīk jayadēv trilōchan nāmā avar kabīr bhanan .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Balh
author.description:
Poet Balh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਤਿਨ ਕੌ ਅਵਤਾਰੁ ਭਯਉ ਕਲਿ ਭਿੰਤਰਿ ਜਸੁ ਜਗਤ੍ਰ ਪਰਿ ਛਾਇਯਉ ॥

translation.text: They were incarnated in this Dark Age of Kali Yuga; their praises have spread over all the world.

transliteration.text: tin kau avatār bhayau kal bhintar jas jagatr par shāiyau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Balh
author.description:

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਸ੍ਰੀ ਗੁਰ ਰਾਮਦਾਸ ਜਯੋ ਜਯ ਜਗ ਮਹਿ ਤੈ ਹਰਿ ਪਰਮ ਪਦੁ ਪਾਇਯਉ ॥੩॥

translation.text: O Great and Supreme Guru Raam Daas, Your Victory resounds across the universe. You have attained the supreme status of the Lord. ||3||

transliteration.text: srī gur rāmadās jayō jay jag mah tai har param pad pāiyau .3.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Balh
author.description:
Poet Balh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਮਨਸਾ ਕਰਿ ਸਿਮਰੰਤ ਤੁਝੈ ਨਰ ਕਾਮੁ ਕ੍ਰੋਧੁ ਮਿਟਿਅਉ ਜੁ ਤਿਣੰ ॥

translation.text: Those who meditate in remembrance on You within their minds - their sexual desire and anger are taken away.

transliteration.text: manasā kar simarant tujhai nar kām krōdh mitiau j tinan .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Balh
author.description:
Poet Balh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਬਾਚਾ ਕਰਿ ਸਿਮਰੰਤ ਤੁਝੈ ਤਿਨ੍ਹ ਦੁਖੁ ਦਰਿਦ੍ਰੁ ਮਿਟਯਉ ਜੁ ਖਿਣੰ ॥

translation.text: Those who remember You in meditation with their words, are rid of their poverty and pain in an instant.

transliteration.text: bāchā kar simarant tujhai tinh dukh daridr mitayau j khinan .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Balh
author.description:
Poet Balh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਕਰਮ ਕਰਿ ਤੁਅ ਦਰਸ ਪਰਸ ਪਾਰਸ ਸਰ ਬਲ੍ਯ ਭਟ ਜਸੁ ਗਾਇਯਉ ॥

translation.text: Those who obtain the Blessed Vision of Your Darshan, by the karma of their good deeds, touch the Philosopher's Stone, and like BALL the poet, sing Your Praises.

transliteration.text: karam kar tu daras paras pāras sar baly bhat jas gāiyau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਸ੍ਰੀ ਗੁਰ ਰਾਮਦਾਸ ਜਯੋ ਜਯ ਜਗ ਮਹਿ ਤੈ ਹਰਿ ਪਰਮ ਪਦੁ ਪਾਇਯਉ ॥੪॥

author.description:
Poet Balh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਜਿਹ ਸਤਿਗੁਰ ਸਿਮਰੰਤ ਨਯਨ ਕੇ ਤਿਮਰ ਮਿਟਹਿ ਖਿਨੁ ॥

translation.text: Those who meditate in remembrance on the True Guru - the darkness of their eyes is removed in an instant.

transliteration.text: jih satigur simarant nayan kē timar mitah khin .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Balh
author.description:
Poet Balh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਜਿਹ ਸਤਿਗੁਰ ਸਿਮਰੰਥਿ ਰਿਦੈ ਹਰਿ ਨਾਮੁ ਦਿਨੋ ਦਿਨੁ ॥

translation.text: Those who meditate in remembrance on the True Guru within their hearts, are blessed with the Lord's Name, day by day.

transliteration.text: jih satigur simaranth ridai har nām dinō din .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Balh
author.description:
Poet Balh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਜਿਹ ਸਤਿਗੁਰ ਸਿਮਰੰਥਿ ਜੀਅ ਕੀ ਤਪਤਿ ਮਿਟਾਵੈ ॥

translation.text: Those who meditate in remembrance on the True Guru within their souls - the fire of desire is extinguished for them.

transliteration.text: jih satigur simaranth jī kī tapat mitāvai .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Balh
author.description:
Poet Balh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਜਿਹ ਸਤਿਗੁਰ ਸਿਮਰੰਥਿ ਰਿਧਿ ਸਿਧਿ ਨਵ ਨਿਧਿ ਪਾਵੈ ॥

translation.text: Those who meditate in remembrance on the True Guru, are blessed with wealth and prosperity, supernatural spiritual powers and the nine treasures.

transliteration.text: jih satigur simaranth ridh sidh nav nidh pāvai .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Balh
author.description:
Poet Balh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਸੋਈ ਰਾਮਦਾਸੁ ਗੁਰੁ ਬਲ੍ਯ ਭਣਿ ਮਿਲਿ ਸੰਗਤਿ ਧੰਨਿ ਧੰਨਿ ਕਰਹੁ ॥

translation.text: So speaks BALL the poet: Blessed is Guru Raam Daas; joining the Sangat, the Congregation, call Him blessed and great.

transliteration.text: sōī rāmadās gur baly bhan mil sangat dhann dhann karah .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Balh
author.description:
Poet Balh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਜਿਹ ਸਤਿਗੁਰ ਲਗਿ ਪ੍ਰਭੁ ਪਾਈਐ ਸੋ ਸਤਿਗੁਰੁ ਸਿਮਰਹੁ ਨਰਹੁ ॥੫॥੫੪॥

translation.text: Meditate on the True Guru, O men, through Whom the Lord is obtained. ||5||54||

transliteration.text: jih satigur lag prabh pāīai sō satigur simarah narah .5.54.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Balh
author.description:
Poet Balh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Balh wrote five hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. The favourite subject of his hymns has been the transmigration of the soul and continuity of the divine light from one Guru to the other.

text: ਜਿਨਿ ਸਬਦੁ ਕਮਾਇ ਪਰਮ ਪਦੁ ਪਾਇਓ ਸੇਵਾ ਕਰਤ ਨ ਛੋਡਿਓ ਪਾਸੁ ॥

translation.text: Living the Word of the Shabad, He attained the supreme status; while performing selfless service, He did not leave the side of Guru Amar Daas.

transliteration.text: jin sabad kamāi param pad pāiō sēvā karat n shōdiō pās .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kirat
author.description:
Poet Kirat [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Kirat, son of Poet Bhika, besides being a poet, had the privilege of being an enrolled soldier in the army of Guru Hargobind, the sixth Sikh Guru. When it came to writing hymns he chose to praise Guru Amar Das and Guru Ram Das, writing four praises each for them, totalling eight. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Jalap.

text: ਤਾ ਤੇ ਗਉਹਰੁ ਗ੍ਯਾਨ ਪ੍ਰਗਟੁ ਉਜੀਆਰਉ ਦੁਖ ਦਰਿਦ੍ਰ ਅੰਧ੍ਯਾਰ ਕੋ ਨਾਸੁ ॥

translation.text: From that service, the light from the jewel of spiritual wisdom shines forth, radiant and bright; it has destroyed pain, poverty and darkness.

transliteration.text: tā tē gauhar gyān pragat ujīārau dukh daridr andhyār kō nās .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

Poet Kirat, son of Poet Bhika, besides being a poet, had the privilege of being an enrolled soldier in the army of Guru Hargobind, the sixth Sikh Guru. When it came to writing hymns he chose to praise Guru Amar Das and Guru Ram Das, writing four praises each for them, totalling eight. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Jalap.
